channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Come be a Perl developer in the smartest city in the USA
item.description: We arenâ€™t a sexy Silicon Valley start-up with lots of venture capital backing us and swinging for the fences. Instead, weâ€™re an established business with a long-term reputation for being one of the best hosting companies in the world. We arenâ€™t sexy. Weâ€™re comfortable. And unlike most startups, we know weâ€™ll still be around tomorrow.

item.title: Sick of jobs lacking purpose? This Perl job literally cures the worldâ€™s ills
item.description: Want to help push forward the boundaries of medical science? Join a team of brilliant minds developing the software to allow scientists to cure diseases. Based out of the leafy city of Cambridge, youâ€™ll be working for a company specialising in genomics, whose platform aids clinicians in investigating the human genome, identifying diseases and working to beat them.

item.title: Revolutionize and Democratize the Job Recruitment Game
item.description: An Irvine, California-based software company is looking for developers to help revolutionize and democratize the job recruitment game. If youâ€™re proficient in Perl and enthusiastic about other platforms, such as React or Angular on front-end and Node.js or Python on backend, this could be your opportunity to streamline the job market by helping recruiters make better decisions about candidates.

item.title: Do you want to save the world using wit, intellect and a heavy dose of Perl?
item.description: Hippies used to be the ones trying to save the world â€” today the tech gurus have joined them. At least the ones inventing clever tech solutions that make the world a little bit of a better place. This particular company is doing their part by providing charities with online payment and campaign solutions.

item.title: A love-fest of job satisfaction
item.description: What if you had a job you loved, and that job helped other people find jobs they loved? If youâ€™re an advocate of â€˜sharing is caringâ€™, then jump on the merry-go-round of contentment where everybodyâ€™s satisfied.

item.title: PerlCon Europe 2019
item.description: I always enjoy reading Dave's blog. This one is special for me as he mentioned my name twice in the blog. What an honour for me. I am sure you are going to enjoy his event report.

item.title: PerlCon 2019 in RÄ«ga
item.description: Thomas was the first to publish the report of PerlCon 2019 in Riga. He always does that. It is nice to read how the event went for others.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;

item.title: Greed is good, balance is better, beauty is best.
item.description: Damian Conway's weekly blog become treat for all the Perl lover. I personally look forward every week to see what is in next. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Solving two problems
item.description: Veesh played with regex to solve the last week challenge task. Some really interesting use case.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 20: Split String on Character Change and Amicable Numbers
item.description: Laurent is on the case without any issues, following his trademark. He always starts with basic solution and improves the code as he progress further. The journey appears to be so smooth that you wouldn't even realise.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 020: Split on change + amicable numbers
item.description: Choroba very cleverly completed his tasks before the start of The PerlCon in Riga. As always the case he is spot on the task. Please take a look.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - Week 20
item.description: Dave was the first to blog about his solution. He has got very unique analysis skill. Must read.

item.title: Amicable Split with Perl 6
item.description: What a moment, it was for PWC, Arne shared his solution during his talk at The Perl COnference in Riga. I was sitting in the audience and got the opportunity to ask few Perl6 questions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 020
item.description: I noticed, Adam, attempted Perl6 for the first time. Please do checkout his blog.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 020
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 021
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.description: Another module by Herbert after Math::Matrix. Here he talks about how it all started.

item.title: Get top-quality custom name badges for your team at StickerYou.com
item.description: StickerYou doesnâ€™t just allow you to make custom stickers for your business. You can also brand your staff with high-quality, affordable custom name badges. Itâ€™s a great way to increase employee satisfaction & loyalty, amplify your brand identity and let your customers know youâ€™re there to help. StickerYou.com allows you to order any size, any shape and any quantity. What are you waiting for? Get your team branded gear for the new year! Use code PERL10 at checkout for an exclusive Perl Weekly discount.

item.title: #420 - Perl Conference in Riga - 2019
item.description:
Hi there

Last week was occupied with the buzz from The Perl Conference in Riga. It was my second European Perl Conference. If you are regular to such conference then you would certainly know the positive energy that flow during the entire event. However, we all missed, Larry Wall, as he couldn't attend because of health issue. But the organisers came up with sweet idea of sending short message to Larry on the specially designed postcard. We wish Larry get well soon.

I noticed unique voting by the attendees to decide the next venue of The European Perl Conference. I didn't see that in Glasgow last year. There were two choices given between Amsterdam and Cyprus. I voted for Cyprus for one reason as I have never been to Cyprus before. But in the end Amsterdam won the contest by 7 votes.

So, if everything goes as per the plan, I will certainly be going to Amsterdam and meet the local gang from Booking.com.

Last but not the least, there is Swiss Perl Workshop happening August 16-17, 2019 FlÃ¶rli Olten, Switzerland. Please do attend if you can.

Enjoy reading this week newsletter.
